title: Paper: Midwifery FQE June 2016
description: Final Qualifying Examination for Diploma in Community Health Nursing (Midwifery) - June 2016

questions.question: During fetal development, brown fat begins to form at:
questions.explanation: Brown adipose tissue (BAT) differentiation typically begins around the 17th to 20th week of gestation. It is critical for neonatal thermoregulation.

questions.question: The hormone responsible for the secretion of mucus by the endocervical cell during pregnancy is:
questions.explanation: Oestrogen stimulates the endocervical cells to secrete abundant mucus, which accumulates to form the mucus plug (operculum).

questions.question: A Rhesus positive foetus is affected by a rhesus negative mother due to:

options.text: Antibodies of the foetus crosses the placenta barrier to the mother’s circulation
Antibodies of the mother crosses the placenta into the foetal circulation
The foetal red blood cells enters the mother’s circulation
The maternal red cells enter the foetal circulation

questions.explanation: Maternal IgG antibodies (Anti-D) cross the placenta and attack fetal RBCs. Fetal cells entering the mother (C) causes sensitization, but the *effect* on the fetus is caused by the returning antibodies (B).

questions.question: Retention of a portion of the placenta in the uterus after third stage of labour will:

options.text: Prevent the uterus from contracting effectively
Cause the blood vessels in the placental bed to dilate
Make the uterus to become hard as a tennis ball
Prevent the blood vessels in the placental bed to contract

questions.explanation: Retained tissue prevents the myometrium from fully retracting and constricting the spiral arteries, leading to atony and hemorrhage.

questions.question: The midwife will encourage the mother to empty the urinary bladder during first stage of labour mainly to:

options.text: Avoid bladder rupture during third stage of labour
Prevent contamination during second stage of labour
Avoid complications during second stage and third stage of labour

questions.explanation: A full bladder can obstruct fetal descent (2nd stage), cause poor uterine contraction (prolonged labor), and lead to atony/PPH (3rd stage).
questions.hint: It prevents problems with both delivery and bleeding later.

questions.question: Ductus arteriosus is a bypass in a babys’ circulation from:

options.text: Umbilical vein to the inferior vena cava
Internal iliac artery to umbilical artery

questions.explanation: The ductus arteriosus connects the pulmonary artery to the aorta to bypass the non-functional lungs.

questions.question: A reduction in urinary output in prolonged labour may be associated with:

options.text: Antidiuretic effect of oxytocin, pyrexia, dehydration
Antidiuretic effect of oxytocin, pyrexia, vomiting

questions.explanation: Prolonged labor leads to dehydration (from lack of intake/vomiting/sweating), pyrexia increases fluid loss, and oxytocin (endogenous or exogenous) reduces urine production.
questions.hint: Stress, heat, and hormones retaining water.

questions.question: In a normal delivery with a well flexed head the presenting diameters are:
questions.explanation: The engaging diameters in a well-flexed vertex are Sub-occipito-bregmatic (AP) and Biparietal (Transverse). Both are 9.5 cm.

questions.question: The maternal characteristics a midwife will use to diagnose late obstructed labour through a partograph include:

options.text: Slow cervical dilatation, pyrexia, excessive moulding
Rapid pulse rate, pyrexia, excessive moulding
Slow cervical dilatation , excessive moulding, oliguria

questions.explanation: Maternal signs of distress in obstructed labor: Tachycardia (Rapid pulse), Fever (Pyrexia), and dehydration/shock (Oliguria). Moulding is a fetal/cranial sign.
questions.hint: Signs of the mother's body giving up (Shock/Infection).

questions.question: Maternal causes of shoulder presentation include:
questions.explanation: Lax muscles (Grand multiparity) and Uterine anomalies (e.g., septum) prevent the fetus from aligning longitudinally.

questions.question: During the 2nd stage of labour, external rotation of the fetal head assists the midwife to realize that the:

options.text: Foetal body is in the lateral position.
Foetal shoulders have rotated into antero-posterior diameter of the outlet.
Occiput has slipped under the sub-pubic arch.

questions.explanation: External rotation of the head coincides with the internal rotation of the shoulders to the AP diameter for delivery.
questions.hint: Head turns to match the shoulders inside.

questions.question: Match the type of jaundice with its characteristic:

pairs.right: Increased red cells breakdown / Immature liver

questions.explanation: Physiological is normal breakdown; Pathological is due to disease/incompatibility.

questions.question: To prevent neural tube defect the midwife advises a woman planning to conceive to take:
questions.explanation: Folic acid prevents spina bifida and other NTDs.

questions.question: The milk secreting cells in the breast are referred to as:
questions.explanation: Acini or Alveolar cells produce the milk. (Both A and C are correct terms, often used interchangeably in exams).

questions.question: The midwife would formulate the following nursing diagnosis for a mother who develops hypovolemic shock after uterine rupture:

options.text: Fluid volume deficit related to intra uterine bleeding evidenced by vaginal bleeding
Risk of fluid volume deficit related to uterine rupture
Impaired tissue perfusion as evidenced by blood loss
Ineffective gas exchange related to uterine rupture

questions.explanation: The core problem is actual loss of volume (deficit).

questions.question: Select the TRUE statements regarding obstetric conditions. (Select correct options)

options.text: In puerperal psychosis: Restlessness, agitation, insomnia, failure to eat are present
Haemorrhagic diseases of the newborn occur due to hypoxia

questions.explanation: Puerperal psychosis manifests with mania/agitation. HDN is due to Vitamin K deficiency, not hypoxia.

questions.question: Maternal distress can be diagnosed from the partograph through:

options.text: Cervical dilatation, Urine testing, blood pressure
Urine testing, blood pressure, maternal pulse
Cervical dilatation, urine testing, amniotic fluid
Cervical dilatation, uterine contraction, blood pressure

questions.explanation: Maternal wellbeing is monitored via Pulse, BP, Temperature, and Urine (Protein/Ketones).

questions.question: The direct causes of maternal deaths in Kenya include:
questions.explanation: The 'Big 3' direct obstetric causes are Hemorrhage, Hypertension (Eclampsia), and Sepsis. Malaria/Anemia are indirect.

questions.question: Maternal minor complications which may occur during puerperium include:
questions.explanation: Bleeding and Depression are major. Soreness and Engorgement are minor/common.

questions.question: Definitive indications for elective caesarean section include:

options.text: Cephalopelvic disproportion, major degree of placenta preavia
High order multiple pregnancies, breech presentation
Major degree of placenta preavia, diabetes mellitus

questions.explanation: Absolute CPD and Placenta Previa covering the os require CS.

questions.question: Draw and label a diagram of a sagittal section of the pelvis.
questions.explanation: Labels: Sacrum, Coccyx, Pubic Symphysis, Inlet, Outlet, Cavity, Axis.
questions.hint: Side view of the bony pelvis.

questions.question: Explain two (2) processes involved in involution of the uterus. (Select 2)
questions.explanation: Involution occurs via Ischaemia (due to contraction) and Autolysis (enzymatic breakdown).
questions.hint: Starving the cells and digesting excess tissue.

questions.question: Outline five (5) nursing interventions in management of premature rupture of membranes. (Select 5)
questions.explanation: Focus is on preventing infection and cord prolapse. Avoid VEs.

questions.question: Explain two (2) roles of the midwife in the prevention of hypothermia. (Select 2)
questions.explanation: Dry and warm (skin-to-skin) are key steps.

questions.question: Explain three (3) characteristics a midwife will identify to determine low birth weight/IUGR during examination of a pregnant woman. (Select 3)

options.text: Fundal height less than gestational age (Small for dates)
Easily palpable fetal parts / Reduced liquor

questions.explanation: Signs of IUGR: Small uterus, poor weight gain, 'skin and bones' feel (little fluid/fat).

questions.question: For a patient who has undergone caesarean section, formulate three (3) nursing diagnoses. (Select 3)

options.text: Acute pain related to surgical incision
Risk for infection related to surgical wound
Risk for fluid volume deficit related to blood loss
Ineffective breastfeeding related to lack of milk

questions.explanation: Post-op priorities: Pain, Infection, Bleeding/Fluid balance.

questions.question: Explain three (3) hospital related factors that can reduce maternal mortality rate. (Select 3)
questions.explanation: Staff, Stuff, and Systems save lives.

questions.question: State four (4) key points a service provider should consider before providing sulfadoxine pyrimethamine (SP) to a pregnant woman. (Select 4)

options.text: Interval of at least 4 weeks since last dose

questions.explanation: SP Safety: Timing, Allergies, Drug Interactions (Septrin), Dosing interval.

questions.question: Mrs. Kokigoyoo (29 weeks) comes for ANC. Select the appropriate care components. (Select 4)
questions.explanation: Routine ANC involves Assessment, Prevention, and Education.

questions.question: Arrange the steps for Lovset's Maneuver (Breech with extended arms) in order:

items.text: Hold baby by bony pelvis (thumbs on sacrum)
Rotate 180 degrees to bring posterior arm anterior
Deliver anterior arm by sweeping down
Rotate back 180 degrees to deliver second arm

questions.explanation: Rotation moves the posterior arm to the anterior space (under pubic arch) where there is room to deliver it.
